etymologies: mid 18th century; earliest use found in The London Magazine. From French pantin, further etymology uncertain

definitions: A puppet-like toy, usually of pasteboard, consisting of a figure of a human being (sometimes a caricature of a famous person) with a jointed body and limbs moved by pulling a thread or wire.

notes.text: Invented in France in the mid 18th century and fashionable throughout the rest of the century.
